body:
Btw, when attempting to use the branch operator, I am getting a "import error" on the line trying to import the branch python operator. (from airflow.operators import BranchPythonOperator)

i am using v1.1.1. is the branch operator only available in a specific version or release of airflow ?
Thanks -- makes sense.
@smnaveen the operator showed up in 1.2.0 if I am correct, but I would recommend using the latest release (There have been a decent amount of bug fixes since)
I can merge all of this into my original or we can just merge this one. :-D
Thanks!
closing PR as a result of #292 merge. thanks @mistercrunch

Hi @smnaveen, yes you would need to upgrade to at least 1.2.0, but would recommend you update to latest.
`pip install --upgrade airflow` with the appropriate extras should be fine. Let me know if you need more info.

Yeah no streaming pipelines, it's out of scope for Airflow as Python probably isn't the right language for this and there are great solutions out there (Storm, Spark Streaming, Samza, ...). Airflow is really just an "orchestrator", mostly telling other systems what to do. It can take on some serious workload since it is a distributed system, but real computation at scale should be shipped off of Airflow to a real computation solution.

As for Azkaban and Oozie, one of the key difference is a static declarative approach (xml/yaml config files) versus Airflow's dynamic approach to programmatically define pipelines (a DSL). Luigi is also programmatic, but creating a task requires deriving a class as opposed to instantiating it (in Airflow), which makes it somewhat less dynamic. 

From the Airflow docs: "When workflows are defined as code, they becomes more dynamic, maintainable, versionable, testable, and collaborative."

If are interested in streaming pipelines in Python, Luigi or Spark Streaming are probably a better solution.
Seen some tasks that got triggered that shouldn't have been triggered. This requires more testing.

Probably I am doing sth horribly wrong, help would still be appreciated

1) I could not find a MySqlCheckOperator so I copied the PrestoCheckOperator and adjusted it to work with MySQL --> this went fine
2) I adjusted the **init**.py file in the operators folder such that it would know the MySqlCheckOperator as well --> this went fine

Now, what happens is this: When I start my DAG, it imports everything correctly but crashes when the MySqlCheckOperator is called. 

This is the error message:
TypeError: get_first() got an unexpected keyword argument 'hql'

To me it looks as if the CheckOperator does not distinguish between sql and hql and therefore sends the hql argument to the get_first() function from MySql that expects sql. 

My Solution: I changed _manually_ in the check_operator.py file 'hql=' into 'sql=' in the get_first() function calls. Positive: It Works! Negative: This is probably not the way it should be done.

Any advice?

Thanks again for your help :)

Is there anything special I need to do to get celery working? I was under the impression it should work out of the box.. I'm running a fresh install here.

Is it possible to have some more documentation around this? The documentation helps with getting started, but doesnt really hint at what a production configuration should look like.
This seems to be the same issue as #208
Thank you!

Can I ask which version of airflow you are using? 

I remember hitting a similar bug that I fixed by 1) upgrading my version of airflow to the latest 2) Making sure that my `AIRFLOW_HOME` was set correctly  and that the `DAGS_FOLDER` was correctly entered in my `airflow.cfg` file.

@mistercrunch at least for me, this doesn't work. The first migration file `e3a246e0dc1_current_schema.py` creates the `is_encrypted` column in the `connections` table, and then `1507a7289a2f_create_is_encrypted.py` tries to add it again, resulting in:

```
ProgrammingError: (psycopg2.ProgrammingError) column "is_encrypted" of relation "connection" already exists
 [SQL: 'ALTER TABLE connection ADD COLUMN is_encrypted BOOLEAN']
```

Can't run `airflow resetdb` or `airflow initdb`.

In addition, I think `airflow resetdb` needs to drop (or reset) the `alembic_version` table. Otherwise the upgrade step never runs after dropping all the airflow tables because it checks `alembic_version` and sees that all is well.

edit: looks like maybe alembic should take care of this, but perhaps it isn't happening because of the other errors?
Thank you @artwr. I will upgrade as advised and try it out.

This should help:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/d7554d8cc8a7c2d9227b1b76a32867a4673a82b9

Unfortunately I don't think this works -- it needs an additional guard:

``` python

    if 'connection' in inspector.get_table_names(): # <<< This is the guard
        col_names = [col['name'] for col in inspector.get_columns('connection')]

        if 'is_encrypted' not in col_names:
            op.add_column(
                'connection',
                sa.Column('is_encrypted', sa.Boolean, unique=False, default=False))

            conn = op.get_bind()
            conn.execute(
                connectionhelper.update().values(is_encrypted=False)
            )
```

Alembic seems to run all the migrations before actually doing any work, so someone starting fresh (or running `resetdb`) won't have a `connection` table yet. In that case, checking the columns of `connection` raises an error.

the import_error table migration is failing on my machine, for the same reason -- it gets "created" (but not actually built in the db) in the first migration version, and then the third migration version checks if it exists in the db (which it doesn't) and creates it again, resulting in two creation statements. 

I suspect that airflow can't be installed in its current form, since the `initdb` will fail.

In general, I think there shouldn't be any guards in Alembic versions; the whole idea is that you can run them sequentially. This is only an issue because we need to  seamlessly migrate users from pre-alembic Airflow and that means skipping certain steps (for tables they already have).

So I think the proper way to do this is:
1. keep the first migration version largely as is, but remove the `is_encrypted` field from `connection` table, and add the `xcom` table. Then this first migration file is basically "this is what a pre-alembic Airflow user looks like" and can be full of guards against existing tables.
2. create a migration version file for adding "is_encrypted" that has no guards against it already existing. (or maybe we need one guard for users who have installed Airflow since yesterday)
3. create any future migration versions without guards...

This workflow should support existing users AND new users (including `resetdb`) without complication introduced by worrying about guards. I'll submit a PR for it if you like.

Turns out PrestoCheckOperator was the only implementation of CheckOperator and was a bit shortsighted. Here's something that should help derive CheckOperator:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/311
thanks so much for the quick fix! much appreciated

Nice. Thanks for doing this. Removing `airflow/migrations/versions/13eb55f81627_add_xcom_and_import_error.py` creates problem for those of us who are up to that version... Maybe just leave dummy upgrade / downgrade methods  as `pass`?

I went through [Web-Authentication](http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/installation.html#web-authentication) and [default-login.py](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/default_login.py).
Can some one kindly confirm if modifying default-login.py should be sufficient for this requirement? (Basic auth + restricted views) or would I need to write some plugins as mentioned [here](http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/plugins.html).

There are 3 levels of access to the UI, the basic, the data profiling (+data profiling menu) and the superuser (admin menu items). 

The flask-login hook should allow you to define your user model and authenticate in a way that makes sense in your environment (ldap, openid, password, authentication reverse proxy, ...).

As to different people seeing different DAGs, are you doing it to avoid confusion, or do you really want to restrict someone from seeing someone else's DAGs? If you want to restrict you'll probably need to add it as a new security access level.

Which version are you using?  Also for clarity we tend to put an even `start_date` as in `2015-01-01T00:00:00` and use a `TimeSensor` to delay task execution to say `17:35:00`.

Anyhow the tree view should look ok either way, I think a fix was pushed for this recently.

`airflow version` will print the version
`pip install airflow --upgrade` to move up to the latest version

This looks very specific to your environment. Airflow is upfront about the command it is running:
`beeline -n user -p pwd -f /tmp/airflow_hiveop_aaHpS2/tmpZYKIxL -u jdbc:hive2://10.192.11.26:10000/default;auth=noSasl`

I bet you if you run this in the same context (replace the tmp file by a simple file with a dummy hql statement in it) it won't work.
Can you please add a unit test that makes sure that DAGs are == to themselves and different from others?
What about adding a url parameter `nocollapse=true` to force your alternate view? Maybe compute the size of the tree and fallback on this view if the tree goes over a limit?
Added unit tests. One day these could go in a "DAG" section.
We're honored to have Jampp on board!

This is nice. I'm thinking that a max number of nodes would be less arbitrary than a timeout. The problems seem to me more around how many nodes can be pushed over the network (tens of thousands) or most likely how many the d3 lib can render. I have no idea how many nodes can be generated in 1 second...

The real solution is probably for the d3 example I tweaked to be changed to operate on a graph instead of a tree structure, but that does sound like a can of worms.

I'm not in love with the timeout idea either, but unfortunately the issue isn't as much about the number of nodes as it is about (exponentially) how many times they recombine. The example in #299 only has 50 nodes, but it's enough to totally crash my web server and require a hard restart.  In the absence of a good heuristic ~~(which there could be, I'm just not sure what it is!)~~, at least the timeout loosely corresponds to "amount of user frustration".

Edit -- maybe what you're suggesting is count the number of nodes during the traversal (including recombinations), and if you reach a certain number, abort? That could work! It might be possible to end up with "partial" expand collapse support -- do it until we hit a threshold number of nodes, then finish the rest the quick way. Let me see.
Do we have a reasonable idea on the number of the number of nodes that can reasonably be rendered by d3 on a reasonable machine? ~10k ? 5k?

As long as you start_date, or latest run is a `Friday`, the schedule_interval will get applied to it and it should be all good. One thing to keep in mind is that much like in the daily schedule_interval context, `2015-01-01` run is for the `2015-01-01` to `2015-01-02` and gets triggered at 00:00 on `2015-01-02`, on a weekly run labeled `2015-01-01` will get kicked off on `2015-01-08`, and that run should represent that period.

Yes, I meant to count the number of tree nodes during traversal and aborting when you reach a number. I think it must be somewhere between 500 and 10k.

Maybe you'll be able to test different limits as you move the constant around while playing with the code, and find a sensible default.

Running some experiments on the pathological graph from #299: it generates 122,221 nodes (!) in about 12 seconds. Building the json takes another minute. I've never waited for d3 to finish.

Here are some benchmarks for stopping at different points:
100 nodes: 0.01 seconds to recurse, 0.06 seconds to write json, 0.1 seconds to display d3
1,000 nodes: 0.1 seconds to recurse, 0.45 seconds to write json, 0.1 seconds to display d3
5,000 nodes: 0.5 seconds to recurse, 2.2 seconds to write son, 0.3 seconds to display d3
10,000 nodes: 1 second to recurse, 5 seconds to write json, 0.5 seconds to display d3

Good news -- recursing and writing are basically linear in time, but d3 starts to get aggravated above 1000 nodes. This is on a reasonably powerful CPU though.

Should we say 5,000 nodes as a cutoff? After that, we finish the recursion using the quick method. So the whole tree is definitely shown and _mostly_ has fancy functionality.

5k sounds reasonable! And people can always use the filter/root functionality

It's the filter button here if you haven't noticed it before:
![screen shot 2015-08-27 at 3 29 42 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/487433/9534866/b402cec6-4cd0-11e5-9e5d-12c4159dac8e.png)

Hi @mistercrunch 
Thanks for the reply. So as I understand, flask-login hook gives me 
1. Authentication and 
2. Access level as you mention.
We also need 
3. DAGs filtering based on owner
So can be taken up as a potential contribution.

However, right now, I am struggling with flask-login. I am a python noob and trying to understand how it works. I copied default_login as airflow_login to pythonpath, and is picked up correctly (also set authenticate=true). However, it results in an infinite loop between 
GET /admin and
GET /admin/airflow/login?next=/admin

So is there some minimal modification I can / need to do to the airflow_login.py to make it work?

I was hoping something like a basic authentication popup to show with DEFAULT_USER (i.e. airflow) as valid username, and something (say secret_key?) as password.

I guess going through flask login tutorials available online will probably help, but some immediate suggestions to make it work will allow me to get on board quickly.

Thanks.

Here's an example of how this can be done. We use an internal authentication reverse proxy that authenticates and adds information in http headers

```
import flask_login

from flask_login import login_required, current_user, logout_user
from flask import url_for, redirect

from airflow import settings
from airflow import models

from sqlalchemy.types import PickleType
from sqlalchemy import Column

import urllib2
import re


ACCEPTED_ROLES= [
    'Some secret roles'
]

login_manager = flask_login.LoginManager()
login_manager.login_view = 'airflow.login'  # Calls login() bellow
login_manager.login_message = None

class User (models.BaseUser):
    roles = Column(PickleType())

    def is_active(self):
        '''Required by flask_login'''
        return True

    def is_authenticated(self):
        '''Required by flask_login'''
        return True

    def is_anonymous(self):
        '''Required by flask_login'''
        return False

    def data_profiling(self):
        '''Provides access to data profiling tools'''
        roles = self.roles or []
        return any([g in ACCEPTED_ROLES for g in roles])

    def is_superuser(self):
        '''Access all the things'''
        roles = self.roles or []
        return any([g in ACCEPTED_ROLES for g in roles])
models.User = User
del User


@login_manager.user_loader
def load_user(userid):
    session = settings.Session()
    user = session.query(models.User).filter(models.User.id == userid).first()
    session.expunge_all()
    session.commit()
    session.close()
    return user


def login(self, request):
    session = settings.Session()

    has_access = some_secret_internal_stuff()

    if has_access:
        user = session.query(models.User).filter(
            models.User.username == username).first()
        if not user:
            user = models.User(username=username)
        user.email = email
        user.roles = groups
        session.merge(user)
        session.commit()
        # this is important
        flask_login.login_user(user)
        session.commit()
        session.close()
        return redirect(request.args.get("next") or url_for("index"))
    else:
        return redirect(url_for('airflow.noaccess'))

```

Thanks @mistercrunch 
Although the code above gives me an error on compilation -

```
sqlalchemy.exc.ArgumentError: Column 'roles' on class <class '__main__.User'> conflicts with existing column 'user.roles'
```

But I got the crux of why the default_login.py was not working.

default_login.py has -

```
def login(self, request):
# ----- some stuff ---
    session.merge(user)
    session.expunge_all()
    session.commit()
    session.close()
    flask_login.login_user(user)
    return redirect(request.args.get("next") or url_for("index"))
```

It results in an infinite loop.

While the snippet you gave has -

```
def login(self, request):
# ----- some stuff ---
        session.merge(user)
        session.commit()
        flask_login.login_user(user)
        session.commit()
        session.close()
        return redirect(request.args.get("next") or url_for("index"))
```

Which works perfectly :) 
I think we should fix it in default_login.py as well.
Again, thanks for getting me started on this. Will continue on this and update.

OS : Ubuntu 14.04

That is the point, I had run the context. It work in terminal. But the same command not work in python code.
It was very like the process was waiting for input in the python

Depending on what your needs are, there are several ways to help with this: 
- The first one is to define a DAG with `{'adhoc': True}` in the default_args. This will ensure that the pipeline is not scheduled, and the tasks only run when a manual run/backfill command is issued.
- If you can formulate your pipeline as depending on a particular trigger (presence of a File, or a partition in Hive, or a key in S3), then it could run daily and only run to process that particular file should you chose to.

Of course you can combine the approaches.

Let me know if you need more help.
Well something has to be different between the context in your command line and the python `subprocess.Popen` call then. You'll understand that it's impossible for me to troubleshoot this remotely.

"Backfill seems to run all jobs form the start date"
Well only if you don't pass it a start_date, see `airflow backfill -h` for all the options, but look at `-s`, `-e` and `-a`

The idea with `adhoc=True` tasks (note that it is a task level parameter) is that you can squeeze them in a DAG alongside scheduled tasks and have them around, ready for their occasional use cases. You'd then trigger them with an `airflow backfill -a [...]` command when needed.

Other options you may consider are to pause individual DAGs in the UI, or simply not run the scheduler at all.

You'd have to extend the http hook functionality, many of the hooks use the `extra` column to avoid having to hardcode extra params in the code. The `requests` library seem to offer everything that is needed to hook into.

Thanks for taking the time to write this great blog post! It means a lot to us to read about how Airflow is used outside of Airbnb.

Hi guys,
After some digs, I guess this issue is related to the pickler used in airflow, [dill](https://github.com/uqfoundation/dill). Generally, dill is not able to unpickle modules.

To be short, if you want airflow being able to execute specific task on a remote box, you have to put the 'unusual_prefix_...' module on PYTHONPATH. There're two ways you can do that:
1) Copy all of the $AIRFLOW_HOME/dags directory to remote box, and start task instance with '-sd' argument provided, namely, 'airflow run example_dag .. -sd '. This way, airflow would scan the provided subdir, and import dag modules as 'unusual_prefix_**' names.
    In this way, we're actually not using the pickling feature of airflow.
2) Ask the author of dill to add module serializing support.
    The related issue is [here](https://github.com/uqfoundation/dill/issues/123).

I worked through this again and tried to keep the scope small. I updated the base_hook to first see if the conn_id is an environment variable before checking the connections in the database. This way the connection information isn't saved in the database. The connection model has been refactored to parse a uri and then assign it to all the appropriate properties.

This sounds relevant to my use case. Currently we're using Sun Grid Engine, `qstat` `qsub` and the rest of the `q<cmd>`'s, for resource management (http://www.drmaa.org/). I like the idea of airflow, and it seems possible to add hooks to drmaa in order to make our workflows cluster agnostic. (more hooks in for whatever we may replace drmaa with in the future). 

It seems possible that in my case the operator could simply `qsub` jobs that may or may not `qsub` more jobs as new parts of the DAG? Or is that basically what @martinxsliu is asking?
No problem! On a more general note, should we slowly add all the `from __future__ import` all over the files to prevent making incompatible changes?
Re-open if needed.
It really shouldn't. We have 100+ DAGs at Airbnb and sometimes a DAG or two will go offline as people push bad code and it does not affect the other DAGs, as expected.

Can you double check that `1.4.0` or `1.3.0` did not have this issue by running `pip install airflow==1.4.0` and running your test?

I run the unit tests very often and they cover backfill on a LocalExecutor, so there has to be something else going on here.

Another thing to try to narrow this down would be to momentarily switch depends_on_past to False and see if it helps. The logic is supposed to not apply depends_on_past on the start_date of a task or a backfill, but there may be an issue around that...
For cross dag dependencies, use ExternalTaskSensor, it allows you to wait for task completion within a different dag
